results.title: The Origins of film: the African American cinema
results.creator_credit: Micheaux Book and Film Co, Colored Players Film Corp and DeForest Phonofilms
results.brief_description: Volume one of a three disc anthology of restored early silent American films (1900-1926) from archival prints held in the Library of Congress’s Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division. This volume focuses on early African American Cinema. “Within our gates”: one of the earliest silent films directed by an African American is this melodrama about the efforts of a black woman with a tragic past to raise funds for a school for black children in the South. The film dealt with provocative issues of the time, such as overt racism, lynching, and the sorry state of education for the black community. Micheaux’s use of a mixed race cast allowed for a more complicated exploration of such issues than all-black “race movies” or Hollywood studio productions. “Scar of shame” was one of the few silent films made specifically for black audiences known to have survived. The story concerns an uneducated dark-skinned girl who forces an upright middle-class piano teacher into marriage. While it follows many of the conventions of Hollywood social melodrama and was produced, written and directed by whites it is recognised for its projection of an authentic black point of view and for its accurate portrayal of black social mores, particularly of the caste, class and colour divisions amongst middle class blacks and of the tensions between middle class and street life. In “Noble Sissle and Eubie Blake” the entertainers of the title perform two songs. A booklet containing notes about the filmmakers, the restoration process, the context in which the films were made, and synopses is included.

results.title: The Origins of film: origins of American animation: origins of the fantasy feature
results.creator_credit: Oz Film Manufacturing Co and Vitagraph Co
results.brief_description: Volume two of a three disc anthology of restored early silent American films (1900-1926) from archival prints held in the Library of Congress’s Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division. This volume contains 21 complete classic animated shorts and two fragments of animations produced between 1900 and 1921, and two feature length fantasy films. The animators featured include J. Stuart Blackton, Harry S. Palmer, Wallace Carlson, Earl Hurd, Leon Searl, Frank Moser, Raoul Barre, Howard S. Moss, Willis O’Brien, Charles Bowers, Gregory La Cava, Winsor McCay and Tony Sarg. “The Patchwork girl of Oz”: twenty-five years before the MGM/Judy Garland “Wizard of Oz”, writer L. Frank Baum produced this film based on one of his fourteen Oz novels. “A Florida enchantment” is an unusual gender-bending comedy of manners about a woman who discovers magic seeds that transform women into men and vice versa without altering their outward appearance.

results.title: The Origins of film: America's first women filmmakers: origins of the gangster film
results.creator_credit: Crystal, Universal Pictures, Solax Co, Lois Weber Productions, Biograph Co and World Film Corp
results.brief_description: Volume three of a three disc anthology of restored early silent American films (1900-1926) from archival prints held in the Library of Congress’s Motion Picture, Broadcasting and Recorded Sound Division. This volume contains 3 short films and one feature by early women filmmakers Lois Weber and Alice Guy-Blache and 2 feature-length gangster films. “How men propose”: a woman researches male courtship rituals in this comedy of reversed gender expectations. In “Matrimony’s speed limit” a young man is duped by his fiancee into believing he must marry before noon to inherit a fortune. “A House divided” is a comic take on divorce. The feature-length “Too wise wives” is a droll satire about women’s place in society. Griffith’s short film “The Narrow road” and Tourneur’s feature “Alias Jimmy Valentine” both centre on ex-criminals caught amongst the devotion of a woman, the lure of criminal buddies and the suspicion of a dogged detective. Tourneur’s film is distinguished by its sophisticated visual style which can be attributed as much to his direction as to the contribution of set designer Ben Carre.
results.title_for_label: The Origins of film: America’s first women filmmakers: origins of the gangster film

results.title: The Original adventures of Betty Boop
results.brief_description: Running for 20 minutes, these are three adventures from the animated queen of cute, Betty Boop! “Betty and Henry” (1935), sees Betty offer Henry a puppy if he’ll watch the store. Thats where it all began, and Betty’s pet store will never be the same again. “Betty and the little King” (1936), has His Majesty the King much preferring to be part of Betty’s vaudeville show than act as a proper king should. In “Betty in Blunderland” (1934), follow Betty through the looking glass into a land of enchantment where she meets the Mad Hatter.

results.title: The Origin of the solar system
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 19 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
The Solar system formed from a cloud of gas and dust from which our Sun and the planets emerged. As the cloud collapsed, and rotated faster, it formed into a disk, with a central bulge. The combination of this accelerated rotation, and gravity meant that the tiny dust particles formed into structures known as planetessimals, which eventually evolved into planets. Solar wind cleared the dusts and gases of this cloud after the planets formed. Astronomers study newly formed stars in order to locate possible formation of solar systems and planets.

results.title: The Origin of modern astronomy
results.creator_credit: David P. Stone and Coastal Community Colleges
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Universe: the infinite frontier: an introductory astronomy telecourse”.
The Greeks considered the Earth to be the centre of the universe. Ptolemy’s model of the universe lasted until Copernicus began to postulate that it was the Earth which moved around the sun. Due to his allegiance to the Church, Copernicus did not pursue his theories, but Galileo, was able, with the invention of the telescope, to support the Copernican model of the universe. His ideas were considered heretical by the Counter-Reformation Church, however they sowed the seeds for future observation and theories. The work of Kepler followed, and it is this work, supporting Copernicus and Galileo which bridged the gap between ancient and modern astronomy.

results.title: The Origin of life
results.creator_credit: Adrian Malone, Gregory Andorfer and Films Incorporated
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Cosmos: a personal voyage”.
Adapted from Cosmos the television series by Carl Sagan, this film examines the role of the nucleus in cell activity; describes the process by which an identical genetic message can be made for each cell in a living organism; shows the commonality of all living things on earth and recreates an experimental attempt to duplicate the formation of the first complex organic molecules on earth. Suitable for upper secondary level.

results.title: The Organisers
results.creator_credit: Anthony Cash, Roger Owen and BBC-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Teaching Adults”.
How far do organisers think in educational terms? Have they a philosophy of adult education? Do they know the environment they serve? Are they concerned with the actual quality of the teaching that goes on in their area or college.
results.description:

results.title: The Organ. Part 1
results.creator_credit: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron and World Mirror-Realist Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “We Make Music”.
Simon Preston, speaking from the console of the great Harrison organ in Westminster Abbey, tells of the history and construction of the instrument. He explains the simple theory of sound generation, the problems of providing constant air pressure, and the complexities of playing. Works by Mozart, Purcell and others are played.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Muir Mathieson, Ken Cameron and World Mirror-Realist Films
